exercises.title: Basic HTML Structure
exercises.description: Create a simple HTML document with proper structure including headings, paragraphs, and links. This exercise will help you understand the fundamental building blocks of HTML.
exercises.theory:
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for creating web pages. It describes the structure of a web page using elements. Key concepts:

• HTML documents start with <!DOCTYPE html>
• The <html> element is the root element
• The <head> element contains meta information
• The <body> element contains the visible content
• Elements are represented by tags: <tagname>content</tagname>
exercises.objective: Create a complete HTML page with proper document structure, including a main heading, paragraph, and external link.
exercises.initialCode:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>My First Page</title>
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Add your HTML code here -->
  <!-- Create an h1 heading with text 'Welcome to My Web Page' -->
  <!-- Add a paragraph with text 'This is my first paragraph in HTML.' -->
  <!-- Include a link to 'https://example.com' with text 'Visit Example' -->
</body>
</html>
exercises.solutionCode:
Welcome to My Web Page

This is my first paragraph in HTML.

Visit Example
requirements: Include a proper HTML5 doctype declaration
Add a title to the page
Create an h1 heading with appropriate content

exercises.title: JavaScript Variables and Functions
exercises.description: Learn how to declare variables and create functions in JavaScript.
exercises.theory: JavaScript variables are used to store data values. Use 'let' for variables that can be reassigned, 'const' for constants. Functions are blocks of code designed to perform a particular task.
exercises.objective: Create variables to store different data types and write a function that performs a calculation.
hints: Use 'const' for values that won't change
Use 'let' for values that might change
Functions are defined with the 'function' keyword
Use 'return' to send a value back from the function
